messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: An Algorithmic Method of Partial Derivatives

Paper Abstract: Abstract. We study the following problem and its applications: given a homogeneous degree-dğ‘‘d polynomial gğ‘”g as an arithmetic circuit, and a dÃ—dğ‘‘ğ‘‘d\times d matrix Xğ‘‹X whose entries are homogeneous linear polynomials, compute gâ€‹(âˆ‚/âˆ‚x1,â€¦,âˆ‚/âˆ‚xn)â€‹detXğ‘”subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘‹g(\partial/\partial x_{1},\ldots,\partial/\partial x_{n})\det X. By considering special cases of this problem we obtain faster parameterized algorithms for several problems, including the matroid kğ‘˜k-parity and kğ‘˜k-matroid intersection problems, faster deterministic algorithms for testing if a linear space of matrices contains an invertible matrix (Edmondsâ€™s problem) and detecting kğ‘˜k-internal outbranchings, and more. We also match the runtime of the fastest known deterministic algorithm for detecting subgraphs of bounded pathwidth, while using a new approach. Our approach raises questions in algebraic complexity related to Waring rank and the exponent of matrix multiplication Ï‰ğœ”\omega. In particular, we study a new complexity measure on the space of homogeneous polynomials, namely the bilinear complexity of a polynomialâ€™s apolar algebra. Our algorithmic improvements are reflective of the fact that for the degree-nğ‘›n determinant polynomial this quantity is at most Oâ€‹(nâ€‹2Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscript2ğœ”ğ‘›O(n2^{\omega n}), whereas all known upper bounds on the Waring rank of this polynomial exceed n!ğ‘›n!.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A generalization of permanent inequalities and applications in counting and optimization",
        "Monte Carlo Markov chain algorithms for sampling strongly Rayleigh distributions and determinantal point processes",
        "Log-concave polynomials, entropy, and a deterministic approximation algorithm for counting bases of matroids",
        "Hodge theory for combinatorial geometries",
        "Nash social welfare, matrix permanent, and stable polynomials",
        "Approximation algorithms for some parameterized counting problems",
        "Syzygies of the apolar ideals of the determinant and permanent",
        "New algorithms for lineark-matroid intersection and matroid k-parity problems",
        "Two algorithmic results for the traveling salesman problem",
        "Algebraic complexity theory, volume 315",
        "Extensor-coding",
        "Fourier meets MÃ¶bius: fast subset convolution",
        "No occurrence obstructions in geometric complexity theory",
        "Determinant sums for undirected hamiltonicity",
        "Patching colors with tensors",
        "A bound for the Waring rank of the determinant via syzygies",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Polynomials and the exponent of matrix multiplication",
        "Straightening law and powers of determinantal ideals of Hankel matrices",
        "Lower bound for ranks of invariant forms",
        "Systems of distinct representatives and linear algebra",
        "The parameterized complexity of counting problems",
        "Efficient computation of representative families with applications in parameterized and exact algorithms",
        "Operator scaling: theory and applications",
        "Permanent formulae from the Veronesean",
        "Designing deterministic polynomial-space algorithms by color-coding multivariate polynomials",
        "Classical deterministic complexity of Edmondsâ€™ problem and quantum entanglement",
        "On the complexity of mixed discriminants and related problems",
        "Hyperbolic polynomials approach to Van der Waerden/Schrijver-Valiant like conjectures: sharper bounds, simpler proofs and algorithmic applications",
        "Van der waerden/schrijver-valiant like conjectures and stable (aka hyperbolic) homogeneous polynomials: one theorem for all",
        "Power sums, Gorenstein algebras, and determinantal loci",
        "Derandomizing polynomial identity tests means proving circuit lower bounds",
        "Tensors: geometry and applications",
        "Power sum decompositions of elementary symmetric polynomials",
        "Powers of tensors and fast matrix multiplication",
        "On determinants, matchings, and random algorithms",
        "The algebraic theory of modular systems, volume 19",
        "A parameterized view on matroid optimization problems",
        "A combinatorial algorithm for the determinant",
        "Clifford algebra",
        "Topological Geometry",
        "Waring rank, parameterized and exact algorithms",
        "Apolarity for determinants and permanents of generic matrices",
        "On the principles of the calculus of forms",
        "Faster deterministic parameterized algorithm for k-Path",
        "Finding paths of length k in Oâˆ—â€‹(2k)superscriptğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘˜{O}^{*}(2^{k}) time",
        "A note on the gap between rank and border rank"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in An Algorithmic Method of Partial Derivatives, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
